properties.media:imagetext:
International Tributes to the History of Flight
America's First Commercial Airmail Flight :
In July, 1925, Henry Ford purchased the Stout Metal
Airplane Company. A true entrepreneur, he was one
of the first to recognize the potential of commercial
aviation and to seek to exploit it.
Ford Motor Company was awarded contracts for
two commercial airmail (CAM) routes, CAM 6 linking
Dearborn and Cleveland and CAM 7 between Dear-
born and Chicago. CAM 6 became operational on
February 15, 1926, using the Ford-built metal plane
"Maiden Dearborn IV."
A few weeks later, on April
6, another commercial aviation pioneer, Walter Var-
ney, inaugurated CAM 5 from Pasco, Washington to
Elko,
Nevada via Boise, Idaho. Leon Cuddeback
piloted Varney's Swallow biplane.
The full-color cachet captures both commercial
aviation aircraft on the same field. It shows the Ford-
Pullman monoplane which made the very first com-
mercial flight and the Laird Swallow biplane that
brought commercial service to the West.
Mint Stamp: The mint stamp on this Cover, com-
memorating the 50th anniversary of the first con-
tract airmail flights, was issued by the United States
in 1976. It pictures the planes used by CAM 6 and
CAM 5.
Postmark: This Cover was postmarked in Dearborn,
Michigan on February 15, 1984, the anniversary of
America's first commercial airmail flight.
© Postal Commemorative Societv
Primed 451056. 025
